metadata.name: a formless beauty #4
metadata.description:
"a formless beauty" continues my exploration of pure abstract generative art. 

In this piece, I begin with a white field. An abstract pattern of rectangles are drawn on this field, using one of 12 different color palettes. On top of this, a white diamond or filled circle is drawn, and then marks (the term that IRL abstract painters will be familiar with) are drawn over the top of this. These three layers comprise the basis of the piece. 

Things are fairly deterministic so far, but this juncture, a large amount of randomness is introduced to the piece, as the image is passed through a fragment shader that applies fractal noise to the process, resulting in an image that appears to have been painted and then washed out. I would like to thank Melissa Wiederrecht for the inspiration in this regard; her Zbageti piece pushed me to explore shaders and their effect on the overall look of the piece. 

Note 1: Due to the nature of WebGL, this piece may not (probably will not) run in live mode on a mobile device. I've tested it on mobile Safari and mobile Chrome, and it will run sometimes, but the device is very unhappy with it. 

Note 2: Due to the nature of fractal noise and the preview engine in FxHash, the preview image will  be slightly different than the live view. It will give you a general idea of the piece, but the live view will be more vibrant and detailed.

Note 3: In Live view, press "s" to save a 4000x4000 PNG of the image to your system.

metadata.name: Paper Planes #188
metadata.description:
The joys of childhood are too easily forgotten. Paper Planes is a generative art collection celebrating the joy and magic of origami: from the simplest materials spring delightful forms brimming with ingenuity.

In homage to the handicraft of paper folding, we developed a collection of four pens each with a unique hand-drawn feel: Ink, Pencil, Gel and Dip. They ensure each of our ten origami birds are sketched with subtle imperfections.

Many of the birds are folded from patterned paper based on three traditional Japanese patterns: Seigaiha, Kōjitsunagi and Shippō. Other birds are crafted from block coloured paper which provides pop and contrast whilst sometimes birds match their background, accentuating the hand-drawn strokes that sketched them.

A range of layouts bring each mint to life. Birds can flock and fly across the page. They can be confined to a regimented grid or they can escape and embrace the chaos of the currents. Contrasting frames and borders highlight different colours within each of the 15 handcrafted palettes.

If you're feeling mischievous you can press 'C' in live view to ruffle some feathers…

https://www.phaust.art/paper-planes

----------

In live view, press 'S' to save a high resolution download or add '&size=#' to the end of the URL to render at a custom height.

Original artwork by Phaust. Spring 2022. London / Brighton. Made with p5js.

metadata.name: ylb-mess-A #170
metadata.description:
With colors and shapes reminiscent of childhood LEGO explorations, 'ylb-mess-A' explores the assembly process in reverse, using recursive subdivision to create detailed structures instead of progressively building a complex structure brick by brick. Although the tools I use to explore and create have changed over the years, this piece reminds me of the natural creative curiosity that was instilled in me at an early age, for which I am incredibly grateful.

gAAAAABi8WX2fxGEw0vwYJYuWe6LiUl8irYfBw72Gjjfv3kTX0C4R-7rpRjpHpeColYNI3b5THvvhplktkOWeCokfFwnfyvUdurhEMHBL9PI3juEAvnwhY8=

In live mode, add ?size=<YOUR_PIXEL_SIZE> to change the pixel size of the image for export (Right click to save). For example, ?size=4000 will set the width of the image to be 4000 pixels.

metadata.name: Heat Death #788
metadata.description:
Heat Death is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at The Ever-Evolving World of Art, Art Basel Hong-Kong, 2022

It aims to produce variation and detail from minimal logic.

The source code uses p5.js and consists of around 180 lines of code. It has been left unminified for the interested viewer to learn more.

metadata.name: SMOLSKULL #471
metadata.description:
Smol pixelart skull face

Generative art by Mark Knol (@mknol)

metadata.name: KONSTRUKTS #119
metadata.description:
A study of building and destroying. I built this. You may knock it over.

Humans are both creators and destroyers. One of the earliest games children learn to play is building with blocks, then knocking them down. This simple activity is teaching kids about gravity, cause and effect, and imposing their will on the world around them. As children grow older, the gap between these opposing actions widens. The intention behind knocking things down becomes less innocent, and creators aren't as excited to see their work destroyed.

In 1915, the Russian avant-garde founded the abstract art movement known as Constructivism, rejecting everything except for the absolute purest aspects of form and material. This art was used in service of the Russian revolution and utilized heavily in its propaganda, intended to highlight the utilitarian nature of industrial progress. Mainly, building the new Russia. Its influence is lasting, and can be seen throughout art and design trends even today.

When Russia invaded Ukraine in February of 2022, footage of missiles and airstrikes decimating Ukrainian buildings permeated the media. Ukrainian lives, kitchens, windowsill gardens, and family photos tumbled to the ground. Like children's blocks. Things that took a lifetime to build were destroyed in seconds. 

KONSTRUKTS represents this duality in creation and destruction. Stacked children's blocks are rendered in the style of Constructivist designs like El Lissitzky's Proun series, and Alexander Rodchenko's posters. With a simple tap, blocks (or buildings) can be knocked to the ground.

- Tap anywhere to reveal the KONSTRUKTS menu in the top left. Tap the menu for several options.
- KONSTRUKTS can be exported as USDZ or GLTF models to be used in augmented reality or the metaverse.
- Export a full resolution PNG image from the menu.
- If you knocked over the blocks, you can reset them from the menu.

KONSTRUKTS is built entirely with code, using Three.js, JavaScript, and GLSL.

metadata.name: A Bugged Forest #614
metadata.description:
A forest has stories to tell.
About times that were, about times that will be.
-
This project was minted in much unusual conditions. 
We gathered here, by 38 degrees heat. We belong to a crowd who loves stories, of civilisations at stake and deities, of afterlife and worship. We drank and hugged and chanted pagan hymns. We minted the Bugged Forest from our place on earth that we call Hell just for the fun of it. We are passionate, and loving, and angry and desperate. We, people of the soil, under a bugged sun.
-
This project is the long-form version of an algorithm that contains a bug. “The Bugged Tree”’s code was salvaged and stored and served as the core motivation and engine for an entire forest. Its concept is about releasing the control. I am a  byproduct of evolution, an iteration of that specie who wanted utter control, and which at some point, lost control over its own creation. As a generative artist, I chose to welcome the event of chance into my creative process. The symbolism in chance made me feel humble and free. Unwilling to make any change to a story that the Tree needed to tell me, as a listener, rather than a writer of my own idealised fantasies.
-
The iterations aren’t under control. They may be odd and off. We have to accept it. They are also plottable, press [s] in live mode to get a SVG. Attempt the plot at your own risk, as there’s a possibility for it to come near to impossibilities or cause paper or motor damage, and most certainly, a bugged drawing.
-
From Earth or from Hell, with love, yours truthfully, NFTBiker and zancan

metadata.name: Abstract Life #247
metadata.description:
The concept of organic, obtained from living systems, is said to be an effect that, like a plant and a living being, has grown in a completely dynamic manner in different degrees, and no factor except vital forces has prevented its growth. Organic creation is an example of this type. Léonard de Vinci believed in nature; he wrote, "Painting is a child of nature" in his opinion, art should be compatible with nature. His public image of creativity was "innovation while maintaining fidelity" to nature. According to Michelangelo, the form the artist gives to the materials is in the artist's mind and the materials themselves. Therefore, the artist is always in a metaphysical struggle with the form and secrets of nature. This is a revelatory process through which the artist discovers the mass of paper already hidden in his mind and the materials. As an architect, I tried to create this work while paying attention to the structuralism of shapes and forms in creation, inspired by the colors in nature and my experience in painting and illustration.

To spread the vibe of my beautiful community, minters will own 50% of royalty on each secondary sale.
Eighteen different color palettes and three different borders are used in this artwork.
Made in p5js
Created August 2022
Artist: @ChistaAi

metadata.name: 3D-SMOLSKULL #109
metadata.description:
3D smollskull - Limited edition


This is a generative art collab with Reinder Nijhoff (@ReinderNijhoff) and Mark Knol (@mknol)

metadata.name: Boro #123
metadata.description:
Boro is inspired by the Japanese mending technique of the same name, which means something mended, in particular something mended with small pieces of fabric and patterned over stitching. The technique makes the fabric both stronger and more beautiful.

To render at different resolutions please use keyboard characters 1 to 5, which will render the artwork at a square of 1000 to 5000 respectively.

metadata.name: ASCII-SMOLSKULL #239
metadata.description:
ASCII smollskull - Limited edition


Generative art by Mark Knol (@mknol)

metadata.name: trees.on.lake #178
metadata.description:
I just found this nice spot near a lake, where I sat down for a while and decided that the day was quite beautiful despite the mist.

Generative art by Mark Knol (@mknol)

metadata.name: Non Spaces #129
metadata.description:
Generate... 
Architecture...
Click...

Physical Twin: Every owner of a Minimal NonSpace can get a physical BW print of her/his NonSpace made by AxiDraw for free (only pieces acquired on primary). Only owners of a NonSpace can also get a physical copy, (primary and secondary owners) not for free: Contact me on twitter @ismahelios.

Evolutive: Click on the screen to activate this feature. The token tracks its inception date. Every new day, trees, bushes and vegetation will start to grow... with time... Come back to see your Non Space evolve.
Press "s" or "S" to get a 2000x2000 pixels png

Original piece by Ismahelio. Madrid. 2022. p5js.
